dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: We're gonna talk about some science. Do you like science?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yes, a lot.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Oh, very good. You've come to the right place. So we're gonna think about physics. Have you heard the word physics before? Do you know what that is?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah, kind of.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: What's your idea what physics is?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Um, I'm not so sure.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Okay. I just think of physics as the study of everything. What stuff is, what stuff does. So today we're gonna talk about space, and in particular the idea of dimensions. Have you heard about dimensions?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: At the camp I made a 3D printing one.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: 3D printing, good.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: So I don't choose the size, all I had to do was the shape.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: But do you know what 3D means?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: It's three dimensional.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Three dimensional, as opposed to, what is ordinary printing?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: So, ordinary printing would be 2D.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: What do you say when something is one dimensional? What's an example of something that's one dimensional?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Hmm, I think one dimensional might be a circle, I guess, or maybe a line.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: A line is the perfect example

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah, a line.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Because it's one thing that's straight, right?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: [Hank] Yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: So here's some toys. We're gonna build some dimensions, right? So what would you say about this?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: That's one dimensional.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Exactly. It's not really one dimensional, right?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: So everything has to be one or two dimensional before it's three dimensional.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: And how would you find yourself, like if someone said where are you, could you use some words or ideas to say where you are on that line?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: I think I would be maybe there, since I'm facing it.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: But here's what I want you to think about. If I say I'm at this point on the line, I could translate that into saying I'm at the three centimeter point, if I were here I'd be at the four centimeter point, the five centimeter point, right?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: So every point, every location on our little line--

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Has its own unit.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Has its own unit, has one number.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: We need one number to tell you where we are. That's one dimension. That's what it means to be one dimensional. I only need to tell you one number to figure out where we are.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Unlike three dimensional, you have to tell a lot 'cause if it's like a sphere, you kind of have to start using points.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: There you go. Exactly. We're gonna build a little two dimensional space. You wanna do it? You wanna do the honors here? Why don't you put those two lines together?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: If you make it two dimensional is this, a corner.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Exactly, there you go.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Another way is if you have space in between is an angle.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: I think you should be in this chair and you should be explaining this to me. You're much better at this than I am.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: So those are the dimensions. That's how we think about dimensions. Remember, we just needed one number to find ourselves on the line, we need two numbers to find ourselves on the plane.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: I think that would be an X or a Y axis, so--

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: There you go.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: So, do you think we could have more than three dimensions?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: 3D is the maximum of dimensions for shapes.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Well, as far as we know.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: This is why physicists think about things we don't know about. We're wondering whether there could be extra dimensions you've never seen. Yeah. That are tinier than atoms. So, okay. So what have you learned? What do you know about dimensions now? How do you think about dimensions in a slightly different way than you did before?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: So at least everything has a certain dimension.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yeah, do you think you'd be excited if physicists said that they found extra dimensions of space?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: That would be an amazing discovery. The news would be spreaded around the world rapidly.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: I think so. I think you're right. All right Hank, we want you to keep up studying, learn a lot of math and physics and help us discover new dimensions some day. Does that sound like a fun idea?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah.
